Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cretaceous Vertebrates from Madagascar: A Window into the Biogeographic and Plate Tectonic History of Gondwana
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cretaceous Vertebrates from Madagascar: A Window into the Biogeographic and Plate Tectonic History of Gondwana

David Krause, Stoneybrook, EAR-1528273
Patrick O'Conner, Ohio University, EAR-1525915

This proposal is jointly funded by the Sedimentary Geology and Paleobiology Program (EAR/GEO) and the Africa, Near East & South Asia Program/Office of International Science and Engineering (OD).

ABSTRACT

Non-technical Explanation
The latter half of the Mesozoic Era witnessed profound changes in the configuration of landmasses that comprised the southern supercontinent Gondwana, with dramatic consequences for the associated vertebrate faunas. Madagascar lay near the center of Gondwana as it fragmented into its component parts. This proposal seeks to continue a project designed to discover and describe vertebrate fossils in a sequence of Cretaceous strata on the island, to analyze their paleobiology, to place them in phylogenetic and geologic context, and to employ them in testing biogeographic and plate tectonic hypotheses related to Gondwana as a whole and Madagascar in particular. PIs work in the Cretaceous of Madagascar is only at the very beginning of reaching its potential. To date, they have quintupled the previously known species diversity of Late Cretaceous vertebrates from the island and have discovered some of the most complete and spectacularly preserved specimens of Late Cretaceous vertebrates from the southern hemisphere and, indeed, the world. Many new taxa have been named and described. But much remains to be done in the vast expanses of paleontologically and geologically unexplored Cretaceous rocks of Madagascar. Many taxa are known by only fragmentary remains; many others are still to be discovered. With continued work, PIs are confident that Madagascar's Cretaceous vertebrate fauna will become one of the best known and best contextualized from the southern hemisphere and one of the primary standards against which other Gondwanan faunas of Cretaceous age are compared.

Technical Description
PIs propose to continue collecting terrestrial and freshwater vertebrate fossils of latest Cretaceous age from the Berivotra Study Area of the Mahajanga Basin of northwestern Madagascar, which continues to produce exquisite material of poorly known taxa and specimens of new taxa. Although they have published many detailed anatomical, functional, and phylogenetic analyses of taxa known from this basin, many more have been initiated and remain to be completed (in particular, on albuloid and amiid fishes, crocodyliforms, pterosaurs, sauropod and abelisauroid theropod dinosaurs, birds and other paravian theropods, and mammals). Some of this work will entail histological sampling, thus enabling a comparative analysis of ecosystem-scale, inter-element histological variation within single vertebrate skeletons and testing of hypotheses related to possible responses and growth history adaptations of taxa that are phylogenetically constrained, but which exhibit a wide array of morphological and functional specializations.
PIs also propose to continue developing newly discovered field areas in the Mahajanga Basin, which are yielding new taxa of roughly the same age but from different paleoenvironmental settings. Finally, they propose to expand their efforts into the Morondava Basin of western Madagascar, where brief expeditions in 2010 and 2012 yielded important finds and demonstrated the potential for many more from strata older than those yielding fossils in the Mahajanga Basin. Discoveries from these earlier horizons will provide a deeper temporal context with which to address biogeographic and plate tectonic hypotheses. Indeed, PIs discoveries continue to have profound implications for the biogeographic history of the extant and extinct Malagasy fauna and for the relative importance of dispersal and vicariance during Gondwanan fragmentation. One of their overarching goals is to provide a key building block for reconstructing Gondwanan biogeographic history in the form of a temporally controlled, well-sampled vertebrate fauna from the Cretaceous of Madagascar analyzed in a rigorous phylogenetic framework, and within the context of accurate paleogeographic reconstructions.
It remains a priority to conduct detailed stratigraphic, sedimentologic, and taphonomic studies of all sampled horizons in order to provide temporal control as well as paleoenvironmental and paleoclimatic context. More specifically, PIs propose to conduct: (1) a comprehensive analysis of Maevarano Formation taphonomy that will provide taxonomic summaries and maps for each major quarry, and will detail the preservation of the Maevarano Formation?s exceptionally-preserved vertebrate record; (2) a comprehensive report on the geochemistry and micromorphology of exceptionally-preserved paleosols and associated fluvial sediments in the Masorobe and Anembalemba members of the Maevarano Formation, which will provide critical insights into paleoclimate; (3) a study focused on trace fossils discovered in the Maevarano Formation, specifically back-filled burrows associated with an entombed carcass (subterranean scavenging); and (4) a study clarifying and formalizing the lithostratigraphy of Upper Cretaceous horizons in the Morondava Basin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
National Science Foundation (NSF) Division of Earth Sciences grant EAR_1525915 (PI Patrick O?Connor, Ohio University), with collaborative award EAR__1664432 (PI D. Krause, Denver Museum of Nature & Science), assembles a multi-disciplinary, multi-institution, international team of faculty, staff, and students for field and laboratory research related to characterizing a Late Cretaceous vertebrate fauna and its associated paleoenvironment from the Late Cretaceous of Madagascar. The project, entitled 'Cretaceous Vertebrates from Madagascar: A Window into the Biogeographic and Plate Tectonic History of Gondwana,' is conducted as part of the Mahajanga Basin Project and is focused on paleontology and geology of multiple rock units in northwestern Madagascar that were deposited immediately preceding the end-Cretaceous extinction event.

 

Context: The fossil record of latest Cretaceous (~83-66 million years ago) land-living vertebrates from the southern supercontinent of Gondwana holds keys for testing a range of hypotheses related to faunal turnover at the close of the Mesozoic Era. Research on our discoveries to date has provided important information on the anatomy, life habits, and relationships of many groups of animals, including avian and non-avian dinosaurs, crocodyliforms, turtles, fishes and mammals. Some of these specimens are represented by near complete-to-complete skulls and skeletons, some of which include an amazing array of soft tissues like tendons, feather shafts, and claw sheaths.

 

Intellectual Merit: This project features field and laboratory research efforts highlighting discoveries from latest Cretaceous age deposits in northwestern Madagascar, providing critical new data and insight on the evolution of southern hemisphere vertebrates and ecosystems leading up to the mass extinction event that punctuated the end of the Mesozoic Era. Recent publications include the new bird (Falcatakely) and gondwanatherian mammal (Adalatherium), along with a detailed monographic treatment of the phylogenetically important paravian Rahonavis ostromi. Other research efforts seek to further explore the biology of important species such as the abelisaurid theropod Majungasaurus through studies of paleopathology and both tooth and bone growth dynamics in what is one of the best known southern hemisphere non-avian theropod dinosaurs. We further refined our field efforts, with future excavations planned for those quarries yielding small-bodied, 3D-preserved bird skeletons that include soft tissues such tendons, claw sheaths, and feather shafts. Combined with detailed sedimentology and taphonomy, our team is poised to characterize the fauna and its paleoenvironment throughout our core study area. Our team?s widespread use of publicly accessible databases for disseminating data related to this project provides resources for scientists examining geology, biology, and the interplay between organisms and their environments.

 

Broader Impacts: Significant outcomes/achievements of this grant include several graduate and undergraduate dissertations/theses/senior projects. Student projects focused on paleontology (e.g., S. Gutherz, Ohio University; E. Lund, Ohio University; E. Burns, Ohio University; T. Pascucci, Adelphi University; N. Ratsimbaholison, University of Antananarivo), along with the involvement of junior faculty (e.g., M. D?Emic, Adelphi University; Sara Burch, SUNY Geneseo), have led to several important training efforts, many of which have resulted in student-involved and/or student-led publications (e.g., Gutherz et al., 2020) for the project.

Field and laboratory research for this grant engaged eight (8) graduate and 15 undergraduates, with applied activities related to field site identification, quarrying and mapping, and fossil preparation/molding/casting, 3D visualization/digital modeling, rapid prototype and graphics development, and public presentations.

In addition to 17 peer-reviewed publications, one new book chapter, 10 scientific conference presentations, two (2) student theses, and six (6) database contributions related to published papers, the research team has worked to disseminate information from this project via public presentations, museum exhibits including local (Ohio University), national (e.g., Denver Museum of Nature & Science), and international (e.g., National Museum of Nature and Science-Tokyo) venues. Research findings also appear on the PI websites (e.g., https://people.ohio.edu/oconnorp/), project-affiliated Twitter feeds, institution-supported press releases (e.g., https://www.ohio.edu/news/2020/11/early-bird-tall-sickle-shaped-beak-reveals-hidden-diversity-during-age-dinosaurs), and via numerous scientific news outlets (https://3dprint.com/277319/cretaceous-bird-fossil-researchers-use-3d-technologies-to-reveal-beak-developments/).

 

Our research/technical/student team has developed explicit laboratory protocols related to digital preparation and molding/casting efforts, and facilitated production of high-quality replicas that are available for researchers and the public through museum collections and exhibitions, as well as online sources (https://www.undertheskinexhibition.com/dino1). In addition, high-resolution casts and rapid prototypes of MBP specimens have been used for educational and exhibition development through the Ohio University Museum Studies Certificate Program.

Importantly, our team strives to make data (e.g., Morphosource, https://www.morphosource.org/Detail/ProjectDetail/Show/project_id/894) and outreach materials (e.g., https://youtu.be/VrIfX2UgoVA) broadly available through both formal and informal mechanisms. Throughout this project, web and print media, radio, TV, and other venues have shared discoveries related to the project, emphasizing the importance of scientific exploration and discovery, often featuring student, postdoc and junior faculty participants as the key to the future of scientific endeavor. Laboratories of the research team are regularly used for outreach for K-12 and undergraduate students, general public groups and tours, and active-learning efforts related to academic and technical careers in science in the 21st Century.

 


Last Modified: 02/05/2021
Modified by: Patrick M O'connor
